claim: The authors define cyber-attack as state use of computers/IT as primary mechanisms to harm another state's interests, establishing the definitional scope for attribution frameworks (RQ2).
The authors operationalize cyber-attacks by classifying them into three general categories to structure analysis and attribution (RQ2).
Direct intrusion attacks are defined as attacker interactions that yield unauthorized access or control of target systems, a category used in the authors' framework (RQ2).
The author uses specific incidents (Estonia DDoS, Stuxnet/Flame, 2012 financial-sector DDoS) as case evidence to infer possible nation-state involvement from intent, targets, and effects (RQ0,RQ1).
The report notes that attackers iteratively modified server requests to bypass defenses, which is a technical behaviour used as evidence of skilled, adaptive actors (RQ1).

The Stuxnet case relied on malware forensic identification (VirusBlokAda) and technical analysis indicating a specialized sabotage payload targeting centrifuges, used as concrete technical evidence (RQ0, RQ1).
The authors state that attribution uses multiple technical and conventional intelligence evidence types such as malware reverse-engineering, source tracking, HUMINT and SIGINT.
Common technical evidence-gathering techniques include forensics, reverse engineering, source tracking, honeypots and sinkholing.
The authors provide a case-table (Fig. 2) that demonstrates applying the framework to real cyber incidents for policy and corporate decision support (RQ2).
The document identifies storing logs and performing traceback queries as a cyber-attribution technique, indicating logs are used as evidentiary inputs for attribution (RQ0,RQ1).
A 'Linguistic' library is listed among implemented libraries, indicating linguistic features are treated as an evidentiary category (RQ0,RQ1).
An 'IPv4' library is implemented, indicating IP-level evidence is captured as a library component (RQ0).
Schmitt proposes seven specific criteria that are used to evaluate whether a cyber-attack constitutes a use of force, forming an operational framework for attribution and legal characterization.
The Tallinn Manual—a consensus expert statement—incorporated Schmitt's criteria, institutionalizing them in a prominent non-binding guidance document.

The author proposes operationalizing attribution standards by tying the evidentiary burden to the victim state's chosen response, using stricter tests for forceful responses and lower tests for legal/peaceful remedies.
The report notes that attackers iteratively modified server requests to bypass defenses, which is a technical behaviour used as evidence of skilled, adaptive actors (RQ1).
The InCA method integrates argumentation-based reasoning, logic programming, and probabilistic modelling to perform attribution.
InCA is implemented as two models: a probabilistic Environmental Model (EM) capturing background evidence, and an Analytical Model (AM) for reasoning about competing hypotheses.
Environmental model uncertainty is represented by probabilistic formulas of the form f : p ± ε, giving a probability interval for f.
All-source attribution fuses multiple intelligence types to form a holistic judgment using historical TTPs, relevant to RQ0 and RQ1.
The ODNI Cyber Threat Framework operationalizes adversary behavior into four stages—preparation, engagement, presence, and effects/consequences—directly addressing RQ2.
Attribution assessment must consider machine-level, perpetrator-level, and higher organizational/country-level indicators, answering RQ1 about analytic method and levels of inference.
Rid and Buchanan model attribution as minimizing uncertainty across tactical, operational, and strategic levels, providing a three-level framework relevant to RQ2.
Cyber responses can be executed either overtly or covertly, which affects method choice and operational constraints (RQ1, RQ2).

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: The authors assert that any definitive taxonomy of cyber-attacks will be partly artificial and only temporarily accurate, signaling a limitation for fixed frameworks (RQ2).

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: Attributing state responsibility for cyber-attacks is identified as a major practical obstacle relevant to evidentiary practice and attribution frameworks (RQ0, RQ2).

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: The authors argue that legal and factual ambiguity in cyber-warfare creates a safe environment for attackers, complicating evidence collection and attribution (RQ0, RQ2).

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: The author uses specific incidents (Estonia DDoS, Stuxnet/Flame, 2012 financial-sector DDoS) as case evidence to infer possible nation-state involvement from intent, targets, and effects (RQ0,RQ1).

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: The text asserts that attribution in cyberspace is significantly less precise than attributing a launched nuclear weapon, complicating attribution processes (RQ1,RQ2).

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: The author claims that states commonly deny responsibility for hostile cyber actions, which hinders clear attribution and accountability (RQ1,RQ2).

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: The author uses decision-theoretic mathematical models combined with legal analysis to predict a state's likelihood of sponsoring a cyber attack before attack-specific technical evidence is available.

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: The author operationalizes attribution by requiring overlap between permissive contextual conditions and forensic (technical) indicators to identify likely state-sponsored attacks.

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: Given the practical limits of post-attack forensics and disclosure reluctance, the author argues the proposed framework can narrow suspect lists even without technical post-attack data.

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: The authors state that attribution uses multiple technical and conventional intelligence evidence types such as malware reverse-engineering, source tracking, HUMINT and SIGINT.

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: Common technical evidence-gathering techniques include forensics, reverse engineering, source tracking, honeypots and sinkholing.

section: Evidentiary Standards, Confidence, and Legal Thresholds
claim: Environmental model uncertainty is represented by probabilistic formulas of the form f : p ± ε, giving a probability interval for f.
Proulx proposes a strict-liability model that removes the requirement to prove attribution by holding host states liable regardless, shifting the burden to the host state to disprove liability.

Schmitt recommends an indirect-responsibility model holding states accountable for failing to take reasonable measures to prevent cyber-attacks from their territory, effectively lowering attribution thresholds.
The effective-control test set by the ICJ functions to restrict when states may lawfully respond by setting a high attribution standard.
The chapter proposes that policymakers should develop a framework of proportionate responses for different types of cyber hostility to guide political decision-making (RQ2).

The author presents a rough policy framework consisting of five variables for policymakers to evaluate and choose appropriate responses to cyber hostilities, indicating an attempt to operationalize a response model (RQ2).

The suggested framework combines incident impact, policy options, and other variables to map response "levers" across escalating incident levels, describing how the model is operationalized (RQ1, RQ2).
U.S. policy explicitly reserves the right to respond in cyberspace using diplomatic, informational, military, and economic measures, indicating a policy-level stance on response options (RQ2).
The Department of Defense frames cyberspace as a distinct military domain and mandates development of full-spectrum military cyber capabilities under U.S. Cyber Command (RQ1,RQ2).
U.S. officials' assumptions of informal state involvement are presented as an attribution posture, indicating use of intelligence assessments or official interpretation as evidence (RQ0).
